data.sampled: Mongol - Mongolian - The Mongol Empire was a Mongolian and Turkic transcontinental empire centered primarily on modern-day Mongolia, but at times stretching from present-day Afghanistan to Europe. It was founded in 1206 when the Mongols under Genghis Khan unified the nomadic tribes of Northeast Asia. Ruled from Mongolia's capital city Karakorum by the Khaganate (a confederation of princes), its most renowned ruler was Emperor Kublai Khan, who conquered China and established the Mongolian-led Yuan dynasty, which lasted from 1279 to 1368. By the mid-13th century, the empire's territory covered an estimated 24 million km2 (9.3 million sq mi), 22 percent of Earth's land area at the time. Its population grew to 100–200 million people, between a fifth and a quarter of the world's population.
